content: The Act may be cited as the "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act". It establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds. The District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act establishes Natural Disaster Protection Funds as money, securities, or property held in a segregated account by a qualified insurance company in a designated bank in DC. The funds must be invested in compliance with DC investment laws. The District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act requires funds to be invested in compliance with DC investment laws and mandates that excess balances be distributed to the qualified insurance company by the following taxable year. A qualified insurance company is defined as an insurer or reinsurer incorporated and domiciled in the District of Columbia, subject to supervision by the District of Columbia Commissioner of Insurance, Securities, and Banking, and maintaining an office in the District of Columbia with a minimum number of full-time employees. A qualified insurance company in the District of Columbia must be supervised by the District of Columbia Commissioner of Insurance, Securities, and Banking, maintain an office with at least 10 full-time employees, pay required taxes, and be subject to additional taxes on natural catastrophic risk coverage premiums. The tax on nonqualified distributions from a natural disaster protection fund for qualified insurance companies is increased by 20 percent of the aggregate amount of such distributions made during the year.
